articles.title: California leads the charge: why banning polystyrene foam is a game-changer
articles.summary: BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM Politics may often feel gridlocked, but this year we witnessed powerful examples of what’s possible when courage meets action. In our Best of 2025 Politics roundup, we’re featuring policies and leaders that pushed for equity, justice, and real-world solutions that ripple far beyond the headlines. As of January 1st, […]
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Politics may often feel gridlocked, but this year we witnessed powerful examples of what’s possible when courage meets action. In our Best of 2025 Politics roundup, we’re featuring policies and leaders that pushed for equity, justice, and real-world solutions that ripple far beyond the headlines.

As of January 1st, California, the fifth-largest economy in the world, officially banned the use of most polystyrene foam food containers. This move, part of the state’s broader fight against plastic pollution, targets items like clamshell containers and cups, commonly (and incorrectly) referred to as “Styrofoam.” Conservationists are hailing the decision as a monumental step in limiting waste and curbing environmental damage.

“We found that this could eliminate up to 3.9 billion pieces of foam ware every single year,” explained Anja Brandon, director of plastics policy at Ocean Conservancy. The ban focuses on the environmental hazards posed by expanded polystyrene foam, which breaks into microplastics, travels long distances, and creates a nearly unmanageable waste problem.

From ban to industry reform

California’s Plastic Pollution Prevention and Packaging Producer Responsibility Act (SB 54), signed into law in 2022, imposes stringent new recycling standards for foam products. By January 1, foam users were required to prove that at least 25 percent of the products were recycled, a nearly impossible feat, given that less than one percent of polystyrene foam is actually recycled, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

This requirement acts as a de facto ban, nudging the industry toward more sustainable packaging alternatives. California State Senator Ben Allen, the architect of SB 54, emphasized the law’s broader goal: “This is not about banning products. This is about ensuring the products in our market meet the needs of our communities by ensuring they are truly recyclable and sustainable.”

Allen and his colleagues are betting on California’s economic clout to influence global practices. “California’s massive market provides us with leverage to influence how industries behave not just across the nation, but around the globe,” he noted.

Why polystyrene foam is a problem

Expanded polystyrene foam might be lightweight and convenient, but it’s also a major environmental headache. These items often end up in the ocean or as roadside litter, breaking into tiny, indestructible pieces.

“There are much better reusable or recyclable options to replace it with,” said Brandon, adding that foam’s lack of a recycling pathway makes it one of the most problematic forms of waste. Ocean Conservancy data shows that foam ware consistently ranks among the top 10 waste items collected during international coastal cleanups, despite making up only a small percentage of overall plastic usage.

The impact of such bans has already been observed. After Maryland became the first state to implement a similar ban, Ocean Conservancy reported a 65 percent decline in foam items collected during cleanups. “This really does show that these types of policies work when it comes to preventing ocean plastic pollution,” said Brandon.

Industry adjustments and global implications

Not everyone is thrilled with California’s new regulations. Dart Container, a major foam ware producer, has reduced its operations in the state, citing the challenge of meeting the recycling standards. “We are actively realigning our resources to position Dart to meet the changing needs of our industry and customers,” said CEO Keith Clark.

Despite resistance from some manufacturers, the broader industry trend is clear. Erin Simon, World Wildlife Fund’s vice president of Plastic Waste and Business, highlighted the importance of phasing out products like foam ware: “You want to get rid of the things that are the most problematic and harmful in the first place.”

Jonathan Quinn, CEO of the U.S. Plastics Pact, echoed this sentiment. He noted that over 100 organizations within the pact are working on a road map to eliminate problematic materials, including polystyrene foam.

The ripple effect of California’s leadership

California’s ban is expected to accelerate global efforts to tackle plastic pollution. The United Nations is in ongoing negotiations for a global treaty on plastic waste, and advocates like Brandon see state-level actions as key drivers of change.

Brandon noted that state-led initiatives like California’s have the power to shift industries toward sustainable practices faster than global agreements can. “The businesses themselves are recognizing that there are some material types that are just more problematic and unnecessary,” she said.

With 10 other U.S. states and over 100 cities also enacting foam bans or restrictions, California’s example could set the gold standard for tackling single-use plastics. The ban is not just about limiting waste but about redefining what responsible consumption and production look like in the 21st century.

articles.personality_title: California’s ban on foam food containers cuts billions of plastic pieces yearly
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – California, one of the world’s largest economies, has long struggled with plastic pollution, especially from polystyrene foam items like food containers and cups. These foam products are light and convenient but break into tiny pieces that harm oceans and wildlife.

**What happened** – Starting January 1, 2025, California officially banned most polystyrene foam food containers. The ban comes from a 2022 law requiring that at least 25% of foam products be recycled, a target almost impossible to meet since less than 1% of foam is recycled. This effectively forces businesses to stop using foam and switch to better options.

**Impact** – This ban could prevent nearly 4 billion pieces of foam waste each year from polluting the environment. Previous bans, like Maryland’s, showed a 65% drop in foam litter during cleanups. California’s large market is pushing manufacturers to change, even as some companies reduce operations. This law is seen as a model that could influence other states and countries to reduce harmful plastic waste.

**What’s next step** – Other U.S. states and cities are following California’s lead by passing similar bans. Meanwhile, international talks on a global plastic pollution treaty continue. California’s example may speed up worldwide changes in how packaging is made and recycled.

**One-sentence takeaway** – California’s ban on foam food containers shows how strong laws can dramatically cut plastic pollution and inspire wider global action.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Californie interdit les contenants alimentaires en mousse et réduit des milliards de déchets plastiques chaque année
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Californie, l’une des plus grandes économies mondiales, lutte depuis longtemps contre la pollution plastique, notamment causée par les contenants alimentaires en mousse de polystyrène. Ces produits sont légers et pratiques, mais se cassent en petits morceaux qui polluent les océans et menacent la faune.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Depuis le 1er janvier 2025, la Californie a officiellement interdit la plupart des contenants alimentaires en mousse de polystyrène. Cette interdiction découle d’une loi de 2022 exigeant que 25 % des produits en mousse soient recyclés, un objectif presque impossible à atteindre puisque moins de 1 % est recyclé. Cela pousse donc les entreprises à abandonner la mousse pour des alternatives plus durables.

**Impact** – Cette interdiction pourrait empêcher près de 4 milliards de morceaux de mousse de polluer chaque année. Des interdictions similaires, comme dans le Maryland, ont fait baisser de 65 % les déchets en mousse lors des nettoyages. Le grand marché californien incite les fabricants à changer, même si certaines entreprises réduisent leurs activités. Cette loi sert de modèle pour d’autres États et pays.

**Prochaine étape** – D’autres États et villes américaines suivent l’exemple de la Californie avec des interdictions similaires. Parallèlement, des négociations internationales pour un traité mondial sur la pollution plastique se poursuivent. L’exemple californien pourrait accélérer les changements mondiaux dans la fabrication et le recyclage des emballages.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’interdiction des contenants en mousse en Californie montre comment des lois fortes peuvent réduire la pollution plastique et inspirer une action mondiale plus large.
articles.personality_title_es: California prohíbe envases de espuma y reduce miles de millones de piezas plásticas al año
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – California, una de las economías más grandes del mundo, ha luchado durante mucho tiempo contra la contaminación plástica, especialmente por envases de espuma de poliestireno para alimentos. Estos productos son livianos y prácticos, pero se rompen en pedazos pequeños que dañan los océanos y la vida silvestre.

**Qué sucedió** – Desde el 1 de enero de 2025, California prohibió oficialmente la mayoría de los envases de espuma de poliestireno para alimentos. La prohibición proviene de una ley de 2022 que exige que al menos el 25 % de los productos de espuma sean reciclados, una meta casi imposible porque menos del 1 % se recicla. Esto obliga a las empresas a dejar de usar espuma y buscar mejores opciones.

**Impacto** – Esta prohibición podría evitar cerca de 4 mil millones de piezas de espuma contaminando el ambiente cada año. Prohibiciones similares, como la de Maryland, mostraron una caída del 65 % en basura de espuma durante limpiezas. El gran mercado de California está impulsando a los fabricantes a cambiar, aunque algunas empresas han reducido operaciones. Esta ley es un modelo para otros estados y países.

**Próximo paso** – Otros estados y ciudades de EE. UU. están siguiendo el ejemplo de California con prohibiciones similares. Al mismo tiempo, continúan las negociaciones internacionales para un tratado global sobre la contaminación plástica. El ejemplo de California podría acelerar cambios en todo el mundo sobre cómo se fabrican y reciclan los envases.

**Frase clave** – La prohibición de envases de espuma en California muestra cómo leyes fuertes pueden reducir la contaminación plástica y motivar acciones globales más amplias.

articles.personality_title: New study measures and helps reduce environmental impact of wearable health devices
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Wearable healthcare electronics, like fitness trackers and medical sensors, are becoming more popular worldwide. These devices help people monitor health but also create environmental challenges because of the resources used and waste produced.

**What happened** – Researchers developed a detailed system to measure the global environmental impact of wearable health electronics. They looked at every stage, from making the devices to using and disposing of them. This study, published in Nature on December 31, 2025, also suggests ways to reduce this impact.

**Impact** – This is the first time such a complete analysis has been done for wearable health devices. It shows exactly how much energy, materials, and waste are involved. Knowing this helps companies and governments make better decisions to lower pollution and waste, making these useful devices more eco-friendly.

**What's next step** – The research team plans to work with manufacturers to apply their findings. They aim to improve device design, recycling methods, and materials used. This could lead to wearable health electronics that are easier to recycle and have a smaller carbon footprint.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new study provides clear data and solutions to reduce the environmental damage caused by wearable health technology worldwide.

articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio mide y ayuda a reducir el impacto ambiental de los dispositivos de salud portátiles

articles.title: The duo kite-skiing 4000 kilometres across Antarctica for science
articles.summary: An explorer and a glaciologist are kite-skiing across Antarctica with a ground-penetrating radar to gather data that will help understand the past and future of the ice sheet
articles.content:
An explorer and a glaciologist are kite-skiing across Antarctica with a ground-penetrating radar to gather data that will help understand the past and future of the ice sheet

Matthieu Tordeur, Heïdi Sevestre and the bust of Vladimir Lenin at the southern pole of inaccessibility, Antarctica Heïdi Sevestre/Matthieu Tordeur

In the endless white expanse, a small mound broke the horizon. As explorer Matthieu Tordeur and glaciologist Heïdi Sevestre skied towards it, they saw a golden head emerging from the snow. It was the bust of Vladimir Lenin left by a Soviet expedition at the southern pole of inaccessibility, the point in Antarctica furthest from any coast.

This surreal experience was the first milestone of a 4000-kilometre expedition across the continent to collect data that could shed light on its future in a warming world.

“I almost had tears in my eyes,” says Sevestre, speaking to New Scientist by satellite phone from Antarctica. “We felt really humble, really, really small, and it was quite something to see lonely Lenin here just in the middle of nowhere.”

Since 3 November, the pair have been skiing with kites that can pull them at speeds of 35 kilometres an hour or more. It is the first kite-ski expedition to collect data for polar science. The pair are hauling sleds with ground-penetrating radar that can scan the snow and ice 40 metres down.

Scientists have been trying to figure out if increased snowfall in the interior of East Antarctica is offsetting greater melting along the coast. Satellite measurements can give some indication, but Sevestre and Tordeur’s data could help produce more accurate estimates, says Martin Siegert at the University of Exeter in the UK.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

“For a thousand kilometres in all directions, there will be no one,” he says. “And so it’s rare to get that type of information, but as we’re interpreting satellite data [to work out whether] the ice sheet growing, we really need that.”

The pair have three months to get from Novo Airbase in East Antarctica to Hercules Inlet in West Antarctica before the Antarctic summer ends and there will be no flights out.

In 2019, at age 27, Tordeur became the youngest person to ski to the South Pole solo and unassisted. He decided that if he returned, he would try to combine adventure with science.

“It was much better to use kites, because we would be able to travel much further and do science much further inland in the continent where scientists don’t go often,” he says.

Matthieu Tordeur and Heïdi Sevestre in Antarctica Heïdi Sevestre/Matthieu Tordeur

While most subsurface mapping is done by aircraft, researchers have also towed ground-penetrating radar behind tractors to get more detailed data. But this kite-ski expedition would be one of the longest ground-penetrating radar surveys ever.

From the South Pole, Tordeur and Sevestre will tow a more powerful radar that can penetrate as deep as 2 kilometres. Researchers at the British Antarctic Survey want to see if this can trace ancient ice layers from East Antarctica into West Antarctica. If so, it would suggest that West Antarctica — which contains enough ice to raise sea levels by up to 5 metres — didn’t completely melt during the last interglacial period, a much-debated question.

“This is important because it would indicate whether the ice sheet is unstable to the sort of climate forcing it is now experiencing,” says Hamish Pritchard at the British Antarctic Survey.

Tordeur and Sevestre have had to ski through almost 1000 kilometres of sastrugi, wind-sculpted ripples of hard snow that jolt and break equipment in the sleds.

Sevestre keeps a sense of perspective by listening to audiobooks, including The Worst Journey in the World, Apsley Cherry-Garrard’s account of an agonising winter crossing of the Ross Ice Shelf in 1910-1913 and his failed attempt to meet Robert Falcon Scott’s party, who froze to death kilometres away.

“They’re talking about temperatures of -65°C in their tents,” she says. “I thought, OK, I’m not going to complain about the -28°C we have in our tent.”

This research has broad implications for understanding climate change and sea level rise, benefiting global society by improving climate models and informing policy. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a novel method of data collection in a remote and challenging environment.
articles.personality_title: Explorers kite-ski 4,000 km across Antarctica to study ice sheets
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Antarctica is a vast, icy continent that holds huge amounts of frozen water. Scientists want to understand how its ice sheets are changing because this affects global sea levels.

**What happened** – Two adventurers, Matthieu Tordeur and Heïdi Sevestre, started a 4,000-kilometre journey across Antarctica on November 3. They used kite-skiing, which means they used big kites to pull their skis and sleds quickly over the snow. Their sleds carried special ground-penetrating radar that can scan up to 40 metres below the ice surface to collect important data.

**Impact** – This is the first time kite-skiing is used to gather scientific data in Antarctica. Their work helps scientists check if more snowfall inside the continent is balancing out melting near the coasts. This information is hard to get because the area is so remote. The data could improve climate models and help us understand how stable the Antarctic ice is in a warming world.

**What's next step** – After reaching the South Pole, the explorers will use an even stronger radar to scan ice layers up to 2 kilometres deep. This could reveal if parts of the West Antarctic ice sheet survived past warm periods. Knowing this helps predict how the ice might respond to today’s climate change. They must finish their trip before the Antarctic summer ends, when flights out stop.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using kite-skiing and radar, two explorers are collecting rare data across Antarctica to better understand the future of its ice sheets and global sea levels.
articles.personality_title_fr: Deux explorateurs parcourent 4 000 km en kite-ski en Antarctique pour étudier la glace
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Antarctique est un continent immense et glacé qui contient d’énormes quantités d’eau gelée. Les scientifiques veulent comprendre comment ses calottes glaciaires évoluent car cela influence le niveau des mers dans le monde.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Deux aventuriers, Matthieu Tordeur et Heïdi Sevestre, ont commencé un voyage de 4 000 kilomètres en Antarctique le 3 novembre. Ils utilisent le kite-ski, c’est-à-dire qu’ils se font tracter par de grands kites pour avancer rapidement sur la neige avec leurs skis et traîneaux. Ces traîneaux transportent un radar à pénétration de sol capable de scanner jusqu’à 40 mètres sous la surface de la glace pour collecter des données importantes.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que le kite-ski est utilisé pour collecter des données scientifiques en Antarctique. Leur travail aide les scientifiques à vérifier si l’augmentation des chutes de neige à l’intérieur du continent compense la fonte près des côtes. Ces informations sont difficiles à obtenir car la région est très isolée. Ces données pourraient améliorer les modèles climatiques et aider à comprendre la stabilité des glaces dans un monde qui se réchauffe.

**Prochaine étape** – Après avoir atteint le pôle Sud, les explorateurs utiliseront un radar encore plus puissant pour scanner des couches de glace jusqu’à 2 kilomètres de profondeur. Cela pourrait montrer si certaines parties de la calotte glaciaire de l’Antarctique Ouest ont survécu à des périodes chaudes passées. Savoir cela aide à prévoir la réaction des glaces au changement climatique actuel. Ils doivent terminer leur expédition avant la fin de l’été antarctique, quand les vols de sortie cessent.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Grâce au kite-ski et au radar, deux explorateurs récoltent des données rares en Antarctique pour mieux comprendre l’avenir des glaces et du niveau des mers.
articles.personality_title_es: Dos exploradores recorren 4.000 km en kite-ski por la Antártida para estudiar el hielo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Antártida es un continente enorme y helado que contiene grandes cantidades de agua congelada. Los científicos quieren entender cómo cambian sus capas de hielo porque esto afecta el nivel del mar en todo el mundo.

**Qué pasó** – Dos aventureros, Matthieu Tordeur y Heïdi Sevestre, comenzaron un viaje de 4.000 kilómetros por la Antártida el 3 de noviembre. Usan kite-ski, que significa que usan cometas grandes para impulsarse rápidamente sobre la nieve con sus esquís y trineos. Estos trineos llevan un radar que puede escanear hasta 40 metros bajo la superficie del hielo para recoger datos importantes.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se usa kite-ski para recolectar datos científicos en la Antártida. Su trabajo ayuda a los científicos a saber si la nieve que cae en el interior del continente está compensando el derretimiento cerca de las costas. Esta información es difícil de obtener porque la zona es muy remota. Los datos pueden mejorar los modelos climáticos y ayudar a entender qué tan estable es el hielo en un mundo que se calienta.

**Próximo paso** – Después de llegar al Polo Sur, los exploradores usarán un radar aún más potente para escanear capas de hielo de hasta 2 kilómetros de profundidad. Esto podría mostrar si partes de la capa de hielo de la Antártida Occidental sobrevivieron a periodos cálidos anteriores. Saber esto ayuda a predecir cómo responderá el hielo al cambio climático actual. Deben terminar su viaje antes de que termine el verano antártico, cuando ya no hay vuelos de salida.

**Resumen en una frase** – Usando kite-ski y radar, dos exploradores recogen datos raros en la Antártida para entender mejor el futuro de sus hielos y el nivel del mar.

articles.title: Cameroonians shift toward clean cooking solutions with eco-charcoal
articles.summary: Eco-charcoal, a product made using methods and materials that minimize environmental harm, is gradually replacing traditional charcoal in some households in Cameroon’s capital, Yaounde.
articles.content:
Eco-charcoal, a product made using methods and materials that minimize environmental harm, is gradually replacing traditional charcoal in some households in Cameroon’s capital, Yaounde.

Access to clean cooking still remains a narrowly addressed issue in Sub-Saharan Africa. According to a 2025 report published by The Earth & I on “Universal Access to Clean Cooking in Africa,” just two sub-Saharan countries (South Africa with 90 percent and Gabon with 91 percent) had relatively high access to clean cooking. Statistics from July 2025 prove that burning wood for charcoal contributes to about 815,000 premature deaths annually, posing a significant health and environmental crisis. In January 2022, the World Health Organization (WHO) reported that about 2.1 billion people worldwide, especially in low and middle-income countries, still lack access to clean cooking.

In the last two decades (2001–2025), Cameroon has lost more than 2 million hectares of tree cover, with the wood primarily being used in the cooking sector for household and business use. The ongoing destruction of trees for fuel production poses a significant environmental threat as carbon dioxide levels rise in the atmosphere, with fewer trees to absorb it.

Cameroon has recently strengthened its national framework to curb deforestation through a new 2024 Forestry Law, which prioritizes forest conservation, sustainable resource management, and stronger protection of community rights. The law seeks to tighten controls on logging, improve forest monitoring systems, and ensure that local and Indigenous communities benefit from forest resources through legally recognized user rights and participation in decision-making.

In addition to national reforms, Cameroon is implementing major international initiatives such as REDD+ (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation), which supports countries in cutting forest-related emissions while improving livelihoods, and FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade), aimed at eliminating illegal timber through improved governance and trade verification systems.

In a bid to reduce carbon emissions, which hugely contribute to climate change, some households are opting for an eco-friendly charcoal, also known as briquettes, produced from sustainable, renewable, or recycled waste, such as coconut and palm husk, bamboo, sawdust, and recycled wood. Martin Antoine Issepe has chosen this route for his household and finds eco-charcoal to be a long-lasting solution. He explained to Global Voices:

Biodegradable solid waste often blocks drainages and other water circulation channels, causing floods. Transforming this waste into something tangible ensures a good decrease in the number of trees cut down.

Another user, Lisa Tembe, explains that ecological charcoal does not produce black smoke, which causes respiratory illnesses among users. It also cuts down expenses when it comes to washing kitchen utensils:

Since the pots will not get black, there won’t be any need to spend so much on making them clean.

Maurice Wofo, Technical Director at Stema Group, one of the few companies producing in Yaounde, shared the materials used in its production:

We have as raw materials plantain, cassava, and potato skins, coconut shells, corn stalks amongst others.

He says what while the transformation process involves burning, it is done in an environmentally friendly way:

Carbon dioxide (CO2) is released when the primary materials are being burned to produce the charcoal. This is done in forests where there are trees that can further absorb the emissions.

According to experts, the initiative could provide long-term benefits, as primary components used in manufacturing eco-charcoal are household waste, which are very common and can easily be obtained from homes, food, and roadside vendors.

Strides made by the government

Amongst Environmental Laws in Cameroon is the Code of Hygiene and Sanitation (Law No. 92/020 of 1992), which regulates waste management, sanitation, and public health issues linked to environmental factors. The law regulates waste management, sanitation, and public health issues related to environmental factors. These include:

Solid Waste Management: The Code requires the proper disposal, recycling, and treatment of solid waste, including hazardous waste. Sanitation: It establishes guidelines for maintaining public hygiene and sanitation standards, including waste water treatment, sewage management, and the safe disposal of chemicals and toxins. Public Health: The Code helps mitigate environmental health risks, such as those arising from unsanitary waste disposal and water contamination.

Experts in the domain say clean cooking systems are a key solution for the country’s ever-growing population of 30 million people. Muller Nandou Tenkeu, CEO of KEMIT ECOLOGY SARL, located in the country's economic capital, Douala, says:

The existing hydropower plants are not suitable to cover everyone's needs, and with the massive growth of the population, it is the only solution that will help in the upcoming years, and it aligns with SDGs 7 and 13.

He also mentions that the government is fully supportive of the sector, as they have been launching annual calls for project proposals for the National Prototype Support Fund since 2021. Furthermore, they plan to raise the clean cooking access rate from 23.4 percent to 40 percent by 2030, according to the National Energy Compact, to better support young producers in expanding the market for clean cooking solutions. Citizens can look forward to further progress as the government continues to take steps to improve cooking solutions in the country.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a meaningful shift in Cameroon towards eco-charcoal, a clean cooking solution that reduces deforestation, carbon emissions, and health risks from traditional charcoal. This shift is supported by national laws and international initiatives, indicating broad environmental and public health benefits for millions. The story provides detailed context on the environmental impact, government reforms, and community adoption, demonstrating significant positive real-world impact and substance.
articles.personality_title: Cameroon embraces eco-charcoal to protect forests and health
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Cameroon, many people still use traditional charcoal made from wood to cook. This causes trees to be cut down and produces smoke that harms people's health. Cameroon has lost over 2 million hectares of trees in 20 years, partly because of charcoal use. The government is working to protect forests and improve how people cook.

**What happened** – Some families in Cameroon’s capital, Yaounde, are switching to eco-charcoal. This type of charcoal is made from recycled plant waste like coconut shells and potato skins. Unlike regular charcoal, eco-charcoal produces less smoke and lasts longer. Companies like Stema Group make it using methods that release carbon dioxide in places where trees can absorb it.

**Impact** – Using eco-charcoal helps reduce cutting down trees, which lowers carbon emissions and protects the environment. It also improves health by reducing smoke that can cause breathing problems. People save money too because cooking pots stay cleaner. This change supports Cameroon’s new laws to protect forests and fits with global efforts to fight climate change.

**What's next step** – The government plans to increase the number of people using clean cooking solutions from 23.4% now to 40% by 2030. They are encouraging more businesses to produce eco-charcoal and supporting projects to expand its use. This could help more families cook in a cleaner, safer way while protecting Cameroon’s forests.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Cameroon’s shift to eco-charcoal offers a practical way to protect forests, improve health, and support clean cooking for millions of people.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Cameroun adopte l’éco-charbon pour protéger les forêts et la santé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au Cameroun, beaucoup de personnes utilisent encore du charbon traditionnel fabriqué à partir de bois pour cuisiner. Cela entraîne la coupe d’arbres et produit de la fumée qui nuit à la santé. Le pays a perdu plus de 2 millions d’hectares de forêt en 20 ans, en partie à cause du charbon. Le gouvernement travaille à protéger les forêts et à améliorer les méthodes de cuisson.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Certaines familles à Yaoundé, la capitale, utilisent maintenant de l’éco-charbon. Ce charbon est fabriqué à partir de déchets végétaux recyclés comme les coques de noix de coco et les pelures de pomme de terre. Contrairement au charbon traditionnel, il produit moins de fumée et dure plus longtemps. Des entreprises comme Stema Group le fabriquent en libérant du dioxyde de carbone dans des zones où les arbres peuvent l’absorber.

**Impact** – L’usage de l’éco-charbon aide à réduire la coupe des arbres, ce qui diminue les émissions de carbone et protège l’environnement. Cela améliore aussi la santé en réduisant la fumée qui cause des problèmes respiratoires. Les utilisateurs économisent de l’argent car leurs casseroles restent propres. Ce changement soutient les nouvelles lois camerounaises pour protéger les forêts et s’inscrit dans les efforts mondiaux contre le changement climatique.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement prévoit d’augmenter la part de la population utilisant des solutions de cuisson propres de 23,4 % aujourd’hui à 40 % d’ici 2030. Il encourage plus d’entreprises à produire de l’éco-charbon et soutient des projets pour étendre son usage. Cela pourrait aider plus de familles à cuisiner de manière plus propre et plus sûre tout en protégeant les forêts camerounaises.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le passage à l’éco-charbon au Cameroun offre une solution concrète pour protéger les forêts, améliorer la santé et promouvoir une cuisson propre pour des millions de personnes.
articles.personality_title_es: Camerún adopta el eco-carbón para proteger bosques y salud
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Camerún, muchas personas aún usan carbón tradicional hecho de madera para cocinar. Esto causa la tala de árboles y produce humo que daña la salud. El país ha perdido más de 2 millones de hectáreas de bosque en 20 años, en parte por el uso de carbón. El gobierno trabaja para proteger los bosques y mejorar las formas de cocinar.

**Qué pasó** – Algunas familias en la capital, Yaundé, están cambiando al eco-carbón. Este carbón se fabrica con residuos vegetales reciclados como cáscaras de coco y pieles de papa. A diferencia del carbón común, el eco-carbón produce menos humo y dura más tiempo. Empresas como Stema Group lo producen liberando dióxido de carbono en lugares donde los árboles pueden absorberlo.

**Impacto** – Usar eco-carbón ayuda a reducir la tala de árboles, lo que disminuye las emisiones de carbono y protege el medio ambiente. También mejora la salud al reducir el humo que causa problemas respiratorios. Las personas ahorran dinero porque las ollas se mantienen limpias. Este cambio apoya las nuevas leyes de Camerún para proteger los bosques y se alinea con esfuerzos globales contra el cambio climático.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno planea aumentar el porcentaje de personas que usan soluciones de cocina limpia del 23.4% actual al 40% para 2030. Están motivando a más empresas a producir eco-carbón y apoyando proyectos para ampliar su uso. Esto podría ayudar a más familias a cocinar de manera más limpia y segura mientras protegen los bosques cameruneses.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El cambio hacia el eco-carbón en Camerún ofrece una forma práctica de proteger bosques, mejorar la salud y apoyar la cocina limpia para millones de personas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a traditional clay cooking stove gently glowing with clean-burning eco-charcoal briquettes made from coconut shells and agricultural waste, surrounded by symbolic silhouettes of community homes and lush young bamboo shoots growing nearby, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones and greens to evoke sustainable progress and environmental harmony.
